5 - Does the expiration of the wiping duration break Wudu?
So I say, seeking help from Allah alone, relying upon Him: [85]

1 - Wiping over Sandals
As for wiping over sandals, it became famous among the late scholars that it is not permissible to wipe over them. We do not know any evidence for them on that except what Al-Bayhaqi said in his (Sunan) (1 / 288): (The origin is the obligation of washing the feet unless specified by an established Sunnah or a consensus in which there is no disagreement, and there is neither of these regarding wiping over sandals nor over socks. And Allah knows best).
Thus he said. It is not hidden what this contains - unfortunately - of ignoring the Hadiths presented in the treatise proving wiping over socks and sandals, the chains of some of which are authentic as previously explained. Therefore, Al-Turkmani Al-Hanafi critiqued him in (Al-Jawhar Al-Naqi) saying (1 / 288): (I say: This is prohibited, for it has been presented that Al-Tirmidhi authenticated wiping over socks and sandals and declared it Hasan from the Hadith of Huzail from Al-Mughira, and also declared it Hasan from the Hadith of Al-Dahhak from Abu Musa. Ibn Hibban authenticated wiping over sandals from the Hadith of Aws, and Ibn Khuzaima authenticated (1) the Hadith of Ibn Umar regarding wiping over the Sibtiyyah sandals.
(1) (Sahih Ibn Khuzaima) p. 100 Al-Maktab Al-Islami printing. [86]

And what Al-Bayhaqi mentioned from the Hadith of Zaid bin Al-Hubbab from Al-Thawri (meaning with his chain from Ibn Abbas and it has passed) regarding wiping over sandals is a good (Jayyid) Hadith, and Ibn Al-Qattan authenticated it from Ibn Umar).
I say: If you know this, it is not permissible to hesitate in accepting this concession after the establishment of the Hadith regarding it, because as the author said previously: (When the Hadith is authentic, there is nothing but hearing and obeying). Especially after the practice of the Companions, foremost among them the Righteous Caliph Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, as presented. It is what some Imams of the Righteous Salaf, may Allah be pleased with them all, held.
Ibn Hazm, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, said in (Al-Muhalla) (2 / 103): (Issue: If the leather socks are cut below the ankles, wiping over them is permissible. This is the saying of Al-Awza'i. It was narrated from him that he said: The Muhrim wipes over leather socks cut below the ankles... Others said: He does not wipe over them unless they are above the ankles). [87]

2 - Wiping over torn Khuff (leather socks) or Socks
As for wiping over torn Khuff or socks, they differed greatly on it. Most of them prevent it with a long disagreement among them visible in extended Fiqh books and (Al-Muhalla). Others went to permissibility, which is what we choose. Our argument for that is that the origin is permissibility. So whoever prevents and stipulates freedom from holes or sets a limit for it, it is rejected due to his saying, peace be upon him: (Sahih) (Every condition not in the Book of Allah is invalid) Agreed upon.
Also, it is authentic from Al-Thawri that he said: (Wipe over them as long as your foot clings to them. Were the leather socks of the Muhajirin and Ansar anything but riddled with holes, slit, and patched?) Extracted by Abd al-Razzaq in (Al-Musannaf) (753) and from his path Al-Bayhaqi (1 / 283).
Ibn Hazm said (2 / 100): (If there is a hole in the leather socks or what is worn on the feet, small or large, lengthwise or crosswise, such that part of the foot appears from it, less of the foot or most of it or both, all of that is equal, and wiping [88]

over all that is permissible as long as something of them clings to the feet. This is the saying of Sufyan Al-Thawri, Dawood, Abu Thawr, Ishaq bin Rahwayh, and Yazid bin Harun). Then he narrated the sayings of the scholars preventing it despite their differences and contradiction, then refuted them and showed that they have no evidence other than opinion. He concluded by saying: (But the truth in that is what the Sunnah clarifying the Quran brought: that the ruling of the feet which have nothing worn on them to wipe over is to be washed, and their ruling if there is something worn on them is to wipe over that thing. With this came the Sunnah {and your Lord was not forgetful} (1). The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, knew when he commanded wiping over leather socks and what is worn on the feet and wiped over socks - that among leather socks and socks and other things worn on the feet are those torn with large holes or not large, and the non-torn, and the red, black, white, new, and old. He, peace be upon him, did not specify some of that over others. Had the ruling of that differed in religion, Allah Almighty would not have neglected to reveal it, nor would the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, upon whom clarification is obligatory, have neglected it; far be it from him.

So it is correct that the ruling of that is wiping in every case, and wiping does not require encompassing [the whole area] in the language with which we were addressed).
Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said in his (Ikhtiyarat) (p. 13): (It is permissible to wipe over wraps in one of the two views narrated by Ibn Tamim and others, and over torn leather socks as long as the name remains and walking in them is possible. This is the old saying of Al-Shafi'i's two sayings and the choice of Abu Al-Barakat and other scholars).
I say: Al-Rafi'i attributed it in (Sharh Al-Wajiz) (2 / 370) to the majority, and argued for it that saying wiping is prevented narrows the door of concession, so wiping must be [allowed]. He was correct, may Allah have mercy on him. [90]

3 - Does removing the wiped article break Wudu?
Scholars also differed regarding one who removes the leather sock or similar after performing ablution and wiping over it, on three opinions:
First: His ablution is valid and nothing is required of him.
Second: He is required to wash his feet only.
Third: He is required to repeat ablution.
Each of these opinions was held by a group of the Salaf. Abd al-Razzaq extracted traditions from them regarding that in (Al-Musannaf) (1 / 210 / 809-813), and Ibn Abi Shaybah (1 / 187-188), and Al-Bayhaqi (1 / 289-290).
There is no doubt that the first opinion is the most preponderant because it is appropriate for wiping being a concession and facilitation from Allah, and saying otherwise contradicts that as Al-Rafi'i said in the previous issue as mentioned.
It is preferred over the other two opinions by another preponderant factor, nay two factors:
First: It agrees with the action of the Righteous Caliph Ali bin Abi [91]

Talib, for we presented with a Sahih chain from him, may Allah be pleased with him, that he broke his wudu, then performed ablution and wiped over his sandals, then took them off, then prayed.
The other: Its agreement with correct reasoning, for if he wiped over his head then shaved, he would not be required to repeat wiping, let alone ablution. This is what Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah chose, saying in his (Ikhtiyarat) (p. 15): (The ablution of one who wipes over leather socks and turbans is not invalidated by removing them nor by the expiration of the period, and he is not required to wipe his head nor wash his feet. This is the Madhhab of Al-Hasan Al-Basri. Like removing wiped hair according to the correct view of Ahmad's Madhhab and the saying of the majority). It is also the Madhhab of Ibn Hazm, so refer to his speech on that and his discussion with those who opposed. For it is precious. (Al-Muhalla) (2 / 105-109).
As for what Ibn Abi Shaybah (1 / 187) and Al-Bayhaqi (1 / 289) narrated from a man from the Companions of the Prophet, peace be upon him, regarding a man who wipes over his leather socks then decides to remove his socks, he said: He washes his feet. In it is Yazid bin Abd al-Rahman Al-Dalani. Al-Hafiz said: Truthful but errs often and used to practice Tadlis. Al-Bayhaqi narrated something similar from Abu Bakrah [92]

and its men are trustworthy except Ali bin Muhammad Al-Qurashi whom I did not know.
Then he narrated from Al-Mughira bin Shu'ba raised (Marfu'): (Wiping over leather socks is three days and their nights for the traveler and a day and a night for the resident as long as he does not remove [them]). He said: (Umar bin Rudayh was unique in it and he is not strong).
I say: This addition (as long as he does not remove) is Munkar due to the uniqueness of this weak narrator and lack of a supporting witness for it. [93]

4 - When does the duration of wiping begin?
Scholars have two known opinions on this issue:
First: That it begins from the Hadath (impurity) after wearing.
The other: From the wiping after Hadath.
Abu Hanifa, Al-Shafi'i, Ahmad, and their companions went to the first view, and we do not know any evidence for them worth mentioning except mere opinion. Therefore, some of their companions opposed them as will come. Nor did I know a predecessor for them among the Companions, unlike the second saying, for their leader is the authentic Hadiths and the Fatwa of Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him.
As for the Sunnah, the authentic Hadiths narrated by a group of Companions in Sahih Muslim, the four Sunan, Musnads, and others, contain that the Prophet, peace be upon him, commanded wiping, and in some: permitted wiping, and in others: made wiping for the resident a day and night and for the traveler three days and their nights. It is very clear that the Hadith is like a text stating that the beginning of the wiping duration is from the direct act of wiping. It is also like a text rejecting the first saying because its implication, as they stated in Furu' (branches), [94]

is that whoever prayed Fajr just before sunrise then had impurity at Fajr of the second day, then performed ablution and wiped for the first time for Fajr prayer, he has no right to wipe after that. Can it be truly said of such a person that he wiped for a day and a night?
As for the second preponderant opinion, he can wipe until just before Fajr of the third day.
In fact, they said stranger things than what we mentioned: If he had impurity and did not wipe until a day and night passed after the impurity, or three days if he was a traveler, the duration expired and wiping is not permissible after that until he renews wearing upon purity (1). So they deprived him of benefiting from this concession based on this opinion contradicting the Sunnah.
Therefore, Imam Al-Nawawi had no choice but to oppose his Madhhab - while he is eager not to oppose it whenever he finds a way - due to the strength of evidence. He said, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, after mentioning the first opinion and those who held it (1 / 487): (Al-Awza'i and Abu Thawr said: The duration begins from when he wipes after impurity. It is a narration from Ahmad and Dawood, and it is the chosen view preponderant in evidence. Ibn al-Mundhir chose it, and narrated something similar from Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him. Al-Mawardi and Al-Shashi narrated from Al-Hasan Al-Basri that its beginning is from wearing. Those who say from the time of wiping argued with his saying, peace be upon him: (The traveler wipes for three days))
(1) Al-Nawawi mentioned it in Al-Majmu' (1 / 486) [95]

These are Sahih Hadiths as previously mentioned. This is an explicit statement that he wipes for three, and that cannot be unless the duration is from wiping. Also because Al-Shafi'i, may Allah be pleased with him, said: If he has impurity while resident and wipes while traveling. So he attached the ruling to wiping.
Our companions argued with a narration narrated by Hafiz Al-Qasim bin Zakariya Al-Mutarrizi in the Hadith of Safwan: (From impurity to impurity). It is a strange (Gharib) addition that is not established. And [they argued] by analogy...). End quote.
I say: The analogy referred to, even if its correctness were conceded in itself, the condition for accepting and arguing with it is only if it does not contradict the Sunnah. But since it contradicts it as you saw, it is not permissible to pay attention to it. Therefore it was said: When the tradition (Athar) arrives, speculation (Nazar) becomes invalid. And when the river of Allah comes, the river of Ma'qil becomes invalid. How much more so when it also contradicts the saying of the Righteous Caliph Umar bin Al-Khattab. My experience with imitators is that they claim to take the authentic Sunnah when it contradicts his saying, may Allah be pleased with him, as they did in Triple Divorce, so why do they not take it when it agrees with the Sunnah?
Abd al-Razzaq narrated in (Al-Musannaf) (1 / 209 / 807) from Abu Uthman Al-Nahdi who said: (Sahih Chain) (I attended Sa'd and Ibn Umar disputing before Umar regarding wiping over leather socks. Umar said: One wipes over them for the like of his hour from his day and night).
I say: Its chain is Sahih on the condition of the Two Sheikhs. It is [96]

explicit that wiping begins from the hour of performing it on the Khuff until the like of it from the day and night. This is the apparent meaning of all Athar narrated from the Companions regarding the duration of wiping as far as we know from what Abd al-Razzaq and Ibn Abi Shaybah extracted in (Al-Musannaf). For example, I mention what Ibn Abi Shaybah narrated (1 / 180) from Amr bin Al-Harith who said: (I went out with Abdullah to Al-Mada'in, so he wiped over leather socks for three [days] not removing them). Its chain is Sahih on the condition of the Two Sheikhs. Thus, the Salafi Athar agreed with the Muhammadan Sunnah on what we mentioned, so hold fast to it, you will be, by Allah's permission, guided. [97]

5 - Does the expiration of the wiping duration break Wudu?
Scholars have opinions on that, the most famous being two opinions in the Shafi'i school:
First: Renewing ablution is obligatory.
Second: Washing feet suffices.
And Third: Nothing is required of him, rather his purity is valid and he prays with it as long as he does not have impurity (Hadath).
Al-Nawawi, may Allah have mercy on him, said. I say: This third opinion is the strongest, and it is the one Al-Nawawi chose contrary to his Madhhab as well. He said, may Allah have mercy on him (1 / 527): (This Madhhab was narrated by Ibn al-Mundhir from Al-Hasan Al-Basri, Qatada, and Sulayman bin Harb. Ibn al-Mundhir chose it, and it is the chosen stronger view. Our companions narrated it from Dawood).
I say: Al-Sha'rani narrated it in (Al-Mizan) (1 / 150) from Imam Malik, and Al-Nawawi narrated other than it from him, so let it be verified. It is what Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah went to as you see in his previous words in the third issue (p. 92) following Ibn Hazm. He mentioned among those who held it Ibrahim Al-Nakha'i and Ibn Abi Layla, then said (Vol 2 / p 94): [98]

(And this is the opinion other than which is not permissible, because there is nothing in the reports stating that purity is invalidated from the ablution limbs or some of them by the expiration of the wiping time. Rather, he, peace be upon him, only forbade anyone to wipe more than three for the traveler or a day and night for the resident. So whoever says other than this has inserted into the report what is not in it, and attributed to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, what he did not say. Whoever does that mistakenly, there is nothing upon him, and whoever does that deliberately after proof is established against him has committed a major sin. Purity is not invalidated except by Hadath, and this person's purity was valid and he did not have Hadath, so he is pure. The pure person prays as long as he does not have Hadath or unless an explicit text comes that his purity is invalidated even if he did not have Hadath. This person whose wiping time expired did not have Hadath, nor did a text come that his purity was invalidated neither from some of his limbs nor from all of them. So he is pure and prays until he has Hadath. At that time, he removes his leather socks and what is on his feet, performs ablution, then starts wiping again for another duration, and so on forever. And with Allah Almighty is success).
Beirut 8 / 12 / 1370
Muhammad Nasir al-Din al-Albani [99]
